Label: Bark cockroach
Description: These cockroaches are difficult to spot, with brown, flattened bodies that blend in well with bark. Females are wingless, while males are winged. Both sexes live under bark, where they feed on decaying wood.

Label: Australian woodland cockroach
Description: This species is one of Australia's larger cockroaches, and often found in the damp soil beneath rotting logs. Members of this genus are easily recognized by their large, spiny legs.

Label: Black woodland cockroach
Description: These large, glossy, wingless cockroaches are often found in fallen tree back and leaf litter.

Label: Alpine metallic cockroach
Description: This shimmering green flightless cockroach is one of the most charismatic insects of the Australian Alps. Both sexes of this species are wingless.

Label: Primitive weevils
Description: The genus Rhinotia and other belid weevils are called "primitive" because they lack the elbowed antennae and other specialized features of the "higher" weevils. Rhinotia is easily recognized by its long, narrow, pointed body with vivid white stripes along the underside.

Label: Jewel beetles
Description: Like other species in the family Buprestidae, these large beetles are brightly coloured and can often be seen perching on leaves. These beetles are also known as "borers" for their laval habit of boring tunnels through the sapwood of trees and shrubs.

Label: Plague soldier beetle
Description: This striking green-and-yellow beetle is most often spotted in the early spring, when mating pairs appear in vast swarms on buildings, vegetation, and other surfaces throughout Southeastern Australia. Despite its name, the soldier beetle does not bite; it does, however, exude a foul-tasting defensive chemical when threatened.

Label: Ground beetle
Description: Like other members of the family Carabidae, these large, black beetles are fast-moving predators of other small arthropods. As their name suggests, ground beetles can often be found on or in the soil, usually under stones or logs.

Label: Shining ground beetles
Description: These small, extremely glossy black beetles are predatory and often found in damp leaf litter at high elevations throughout New South Wales and Victoria.

Label: Eucalyptus leaf beetles
Description: New South Wales is home to many species of these large, dome-shaped leaf beetles. Paropsines, like all leaf beetles, can be recognized by their wide, flattened feet (for gripping leaf surfaces) and prominent, jellybean-shaped eyes. All Paropsis species feed exclusively on eucalyptus leaves.

Label: Ladybird beetles
Description: The most frequently spotted ladybird beetles are members of the subfamily Coccinellinae, which are typically medium-sized and dome-shaped, with bright red, black, and/or yellow colouration. These "warning colours" tell predators that the beetles are noxious and foul-tasting.

Label: Broad-nosed weevils
Description: Most broad-nosed weevils can be recognized, as their name suggests, by the wide rostrum, elbowed antennae, and scale-covered bodies. Members of the genus Adelognatha are particularly large and slow-moving, and usually found near vegetation.

Label: Click beetles
Description: These long, oval-shaped beetles superficially resemble jewel beetles (family Buprestidae) but can be recognized by their ability to flip or jump by "clicking" a special joint in their thorax.

Label: Handsome fungus beetle
Description: These small beetles feed on fungus and can be recognized by their clubbed antennae and parallel "seams" along the edges of the prothorax. The species Erotendomychus bimaculatus is seldom seen. It is found only in cool, moist, high-elevation habitats in New South Wales and Victoria, where it feeds on fungus in leaf litter and decaying wood.

Label: Soft-winged flower beetles
Description: As their name suggests, these small, elongate beetles are usually spotted on or near flowers, where they feed on pollen or small insects. Like ladybirds and soldier beetles, melyrids are often brightly coloured to warn predators of their foul-tasting defensive chemicals.

Label: Feather-horned beetles
Description: These large, odd-looking beetles can be recognized by their large, delicate, fan-like antennae and pattern of white speckles.

Label: Green scarab beetles
Description: These widespread, metallic green beetles are voracious feeders, capable of defoliating both native and non-native plants. Several species occur in the Australian Alps.

Label: Robber flies, Assassin flies
Description: These large flies are big-eyed, swift-flying predators of other insects and are often seen resting on leaves or twigs with their freshly-caught prey.

Label: Bush fly
Description: Bush flies (also House flies) are among the most common flies in the world, both inside and out of houses. These medium-sized flies are usually black or grey, and do not bite.

Label: Hoverflies
Description: Hoverflies may mimic wasps with their vivid black and yellow stripes, but these flies do not bite or sting and are usually seen hovering near (or perching on) flowers.

Label: Horse flies, March flies
Description: These large, biting flies, commonly known as horse flies or march flies, are not a popular group among Australian hikers. They can be recognised by their huge, often brightly-coloured triangle-shaped eyes and hairy bodies. There are several species that occur in the mountains, and they are most abundant in the summer.

Label: Fruit flies
Description: These small flies are found anywhere near ripe fruit. Alpine species often lay eggs into the seeds of daisies (Asteraceae).

Label: Crane flies
Description: These large, long-legged flies are conspicuous for their slow-bumbling flight. Larvae are aquatic, developing in fast-moving streams as plump, legless maggots.

Label: Mayfly
Description: In high elevation habitats, mayflies of this genus can be recognized by their speckled wings.

Label: Aphids
Description: These tiny, plant-feeding bugs are a favorite prey of ladybird beetles and lacewings. Aphids are often found in large groups on their host plant, with many different life stages clustered together. In early spring, it is common to see dead aphids littering the snow. They are blown up to the mountains from surrounding countryside and die on the snow.

Label: Leafhoppers
Description: Leafhoppers are sometimes difficult to spot, with their flattened, leaf-like wings held like a tent above the body. They are also very small, usually less than 1 cm in length.

Label: Cicadas
Description: These insects spend most of their lives underground, feeding from the roots of trees. Cicadas emerge from the soil in summer, moult into adults, and can be heard buzzing loudly from trees and shrubs.

Label: Stink bugs, Shield bugs
Description: This family of bugs can be recognized by their large, triangular scutellum and flattened, shield-shaped body. True to their name, many species can secrete or spray offensive-smelling chemicals when threatened.

Label: Bicolour xylopine
Description: In the Australian Alps, bees are commonly seen gathering nectar from flowers in spring and summer. At least 22 species of bee occur in the Australian mountains and most feed on several different flowers. Exoneura bicolor is a small native bee that is common in southern parts of mainland Australia, as well as in Tasmania. It is abundant in mountain areas, and is the second most common bee (after the European honey bee) on the Bogong High Plains.

Label: Braconid wasps
Description: These graceful, slender wasps area often seen hunting for other insects to use as provisions for their larvae. Female parasitoid wasps can be recognized by the long, slender ovipositor arising from the tip of the abdomen.

Label: Rainbow ants
Description: These small black ants are highly abundant in the alpine zone throughout the summer. Becoming active soon after the snow melts, they often construct their nests near bogs.

Label: Jack-jumper ant
Description: These are Australia's largest and most conspicuous ants, with huge eyes and jaws. Also known as "bull ants," these insects are aggressive hunters and can deliver a painful bite or sting when disturbed.

Label: Sawfly
Description: As adults, these insects have wasp-like heads and wings but lack the slender, constricted waist characteristic of other Hymenoptera. The caterpillar-like larvae of sawflies are known as "spitfires" and are often found in dense family groups, feeding together on Eucalyptus leaves.

Label: Geometer moths
Description: Although these moths are typically drab brown as adults, geometrid caterpillars are easily recognized by their "inching" gait as they travel across vegetation.

Label: Grass skippers
Description: Skipper butterflies can be recognized by their relatively small size, stout bodies, and characteristic "semi-erect" wing posture. The underside of the wing is typically more vividly patterned than the dorsal side.

Label: Alpine Sedge-skipper
Description: Skipper butterflies can be recognized by their relatively small size, stout bodies, and characteristic "semi-erect" wing posture. The underside of the wing is typically more vividly patterned than the dorsal side.

Label: Gossamer-winged butterflies
Description: These small, delicate butterflies are often blue-winged, but may also be copper-coloured or purple. They can be recognized by their small size, black-and-white banded antennae, and fine white border along the outer edges of the wings. Many species have small eyespots on the underside of the hindwing.

Label: Bogong moth
Description: The bogong moth is one of the most iconic and best known of Australia's alpine insects. In spring, the moths migrate en masse from their overwintering habitats in southern Queensland to the mountains where they stay throughout the summer. During summer, adults can be found in huge numbers in rock crevices, where they remain inactive and live off their fat reserves.

Label: Silver Xenica
Description: This alpine butterfly belongs to the family Nymphalidae and can be recognized by its checkerspot wing pattern with both dorsal and ventral eyespots.

Label: Saturniid moths
Description: These moths are large, attractive insects with broad, feather-like antennae and usually with conspicuous eyespots on the dorsal side of the wings. Larvae are enormous caterpillars, often found feeding on the leaves of gum trees. This group is not common in the mountains, but the emperor gum moth (Opodiphthera eucalypti) and Helena moth (Opodiphthera helena) are sometimes found in montane woodlands.

Label: Long-tailed bombyx
Description: The Notodontidae are a small family of moths found throughout Australia. Although the adult form of these insects is usually a rather drab brown moth, the caterpillars are instantly recognizable for their habit of marching overland in long, single-file "processions". At least nine species occur in the Australian Alps, including Trichiocercus sparshalli. Most adults of this species are white, but can also be light or dark grey. When disturbed, the moths curl up to expose coloured bands along the back of their abdomen.

Label: Hangingflies
Description: These scorpionflies derive their common name from the habit of dangling from vegetation by their hooked feet, waiting to ambush small prey.

Label: Mantisflies
Description: Mantisflies (family Mantispidae) are small predatory insects with clear, membranous wings and mantis-like forelimbs. These can be distinguished from true mantises (order Mantodea) by their clear wings and much, much smaller size.

Label: Alpine darner
Description: These predatory insects are quick fliers with sharp vision. They can usually be seen resting briefly on vegetation near water or patrolling their territory in a loop. The alpine darner is a large insect, growing up to ~10 cm in length. It is restricted to mountain regions of New South Wales and Victoria. Interestingly, although the male of this species was described in 1916, it took nearly 70 years before the female and larvae were described.

Label: Common montane grasshopper
Description: The common montane grasshopper is common on mountains below 1600 m in New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. It is less common in Victoria, but can be found on the Bogong High Plains and near Mt Hotham. Males and females have black "knees", which distinguishes them from close relatives, and their colouring ranges from brown to green-brown. Adults can be found between January and May. This species has short wings and cannot fly.

Label: Brown kosciuscola
Description: The brown kosciuscola is the least common of the four Kosicuscola species that are found on the mainland. Although it can be found in sub-alpine areas of Victoria, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, it usually occurs in low numbers. Males and females are dark brown with black "knees", making them difficult to distinguish from the common montane grasshopper (Kosciuscola cognatus). A thick pale stripe across the top of each wing can usually be used to identify the brown kosciuscola. This species has short wings and cannot fly.

Label: Common Kosciuscola
Description: The common kosciuscola is common in the Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales and northern Victorian mountains, above 1500 m. It is often found together with the alpine thermocolour grasshopper, but is easily distinguished from that species by its grassy-green colour and two yellow stripes that run down its head and back. Adults are often found in high densitites between February and May. This species has short wings and cannot fly.

Label: Alpine thermocolour grasshopper, Chameleon grasshopper
Description: The alpine thermocolour (or chameleon) grasshopper is the most common grasshopper above 1600 m. Males are easily distinguished from other species by their bright blue colour, while the much larger females are mottled brown. The species is found from Mt Baw Baw north to Mt Jagungal and adults occur in high densitites between February and May. Like many mountain grasshoppers, and all of the Kosciuscola, this species has short wings and cannot fly.

Label: Mountain grasshopper
Description: Not a lot is known about this grasshopper, which can be found in sub-alpine areas of Victoria and New South Wales. It is found in sub-alpine shrubs, and can sometimes be seen laying eggs on foot tracks. It is a member of the sub-family Catantopinae, the "spur-throated grasshoppers", which are enormously diverse in Australia.

Label: Wingless grasshopper
Description: Although called the wingless grasshopper, many individuals (particularly at low elevations) have wings and can fly. Wingless grasshoppers are widespread throughout Australia and can be found from lowland areas up to around 1800 m.

Label: Grassland pygmy cricket
Description: These small, black, crickets are common in the Australian Alps. They are usually found in grassland and are very active on sunny days. They are small (7-9 mm), so keep a sharp eye out for them. Like most crickets, male Bobilla "chirp" by rubbing their wings together. At least three species of Bobilla live in the Australian Alps (B. victoriae, B. gullanae, and B. plurampe) but they are virtually indistinguishable in the field.

Label: Mountain spotted grasshopper
Description: The mountain spotted grasshopper is an easily identified species with its black body and yellow or white spots. This species makes its own anti-freeze, allowing it to survive cold alpine winters and be among the first insects to emerge after the snow melts. This species has short wings and cannot fly.

Label: Mountain katydid
Description: Also called the "alpine grasshopper", this charismatic species is highly recognisable. When startled, they lift their wings to reveal a bright, red-and-blue striped abdomen. Males have long wings and can often be found basking on their sides in the sun. They produce a buzzing sound by rubbing their wings together. They are common above 1500 m in snowgum understory, but can also be found at lower elevations.

Label: Alpine katydid, Australian shield-back
Description: This katydid is common below the treeline, particularly in and around low shrubs. It is darkly coloured and has a distinctive jerking motion when it jumps. Unlike many katydids, it is not predaceous and instead eats flowers, seeds, and grass. The only species in the Austrodectes genus, A. monticolus is also the only Australian member of the katydid sub-family Tettigoniinae to occur at high elevation.

Label: Stick insects
Description: Stick insects are long, slender insects that specialize in mimicking leaves and twigs. When not moving, these insects are extremely difficult to spot. In the Alps, stick insects are rare.

Label: Stonefly
Description: Stoneflies develop in freshwater habitats like mayflies, but possess abdominal gills (as nymphs) and hold their patterned wings flat against the body (as adults). This species is found in both mountain and lowland areas of New South Wales and Victoria.

Label: Kosciuszko tinzeda, Stout tinzeda
Description: Tinzeda is a classic leaf mimic, a camouflage strategy common among katydids around the world. They can be recognised by their characteristic white wing stripes that resemble leaf veins. Two species of Tinzeda, T. soror (Kosciuszko tinzeda) and T. albosignata (Stout tinzeda) occur in the Australian Alps, often together, and are difficult to tell apart. Both males and females are long-winged and able to fly and they are usually encountered in shrubbery in the sub-alpine zone.

Label: European honey bee
Description: The European honey bee is the most common and widely distributed of all bees. It is a generalist and can be found on a wide range of native and non-native flower species. It has only recently been recorded in the Australian Alps but is now very common across the Bogong High Plains.

Label: Frit flies, Grass flies
Description: These tiny flies (usually < 5 mm) are common but easily missed. Not much is known about their ecology but, in the mountains, they are often found on alpine daisies.

Label: Owlet moth
Description: The Noctuidae are a large family of moths that includes a wide diversity of species, some drab brown or grey, and some brightly coloured. The caterpillar stage of P. tristifica is strikingly coloured, with a black and white checkered pattern and an orange head and rump. Adult moths have a wing span of ~4 cm. This species occurs throughout southeastern Australia.

Label: Alpine stonefly
Description: The endangered Alpine Stonefly is found only on the Bogong High Plains in Victoria and is known from only 12 sites within this region. Nymphs are usually found in narrow, stony streams, while adults live in nearby rocks and vegetation. The species is long-lived, spending approximately three years developing to the adult stage. Adults emerge between February and May each year, and live for only two months. The largest of Australia's stoneflies, the nymphs are also the top insect predators in streams and eat a variety of both plant and animal material.

Label: Alpine case moth
Description: These peculiar moths are often encountered as caterpillars, when they construct and live in a "bag" of twigs, leaf fragments, or pine needles. Adults are hairy, drab, and rather disheveled in appearance; in many species, adult females are soft-bodied and completely wingless. The alpine case moth is one of two species (the other being the alpine swift moth/grass grub) often blamed for large-scale damage to snowgrass (Poa spp.).
